articles.title: British-Egyptian activist reunited with family
articles.summary: After nearly six years in prison, Alaa Abdel Fattah is released from prison in Egypt.
articles.content:
British-Egyptian activist reunited with family

Watch: Alaa Abdel Fattah reunited with family following release from prison

Laila Soueif, who went on extensive hunger strike during her son's imprisonment, said on his release: "Despite our great joy, the biggest joy is when there are no [political] prisoners."

Video of the blogger and pro-democracy activist, 43, at home after his release shows him grinning widely and jumping up and down as he celebrates with his sister and mother.

One of the country's most prominent political prisoners, he was pardoned by President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi on Monday, reportedly after a request from the National Council for Human Rights.

British-Egyptian activist Alaa Abdel Fattah has been freed and reunited with his family after almost six years of imprisonment in Egypt.

Abdel Fattah was released from Wadi al-Natrun prison late on Monday and celebrated reuniting with his family at his mother's apartment in Giza.

"I cannot yet comprehend that this is real," his sister Sanaa Seif said.

The activist was arrested in 2019 during a crackdown on dissent and sentenced to five years in prison after being convicted of "spreading false news" for sharing a post about a prisoner dying of torture.

Two weeks ago, Sisi ordered the authorities to study the NCHR's petitions for the release of Abdel Fattah and six others, which the institution said it had submitted "in light of the humanitarian and health conditions experienced by [their] families".

His family said he should have been released in September 2024 but the two years he spent in pre-trial detention were not counted as time served by Egyptian authorities.

When Abdel Fattah was not released at the end of his five-year sentence, his mother Laila Soueif started an extensive hunger strike to call for his release.

She was hospitalised at St Thomas' Hospital in London and came close to death twice during the 287-day strike, which ended on 14 July after then-Foreign Secretary David Lammy told Parliament he "expected [Abdel Fattah] to be released" on 25 June.

Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer had previously said he would secure Abdel Fattah's freedom and there has been widespread cross-parliamentary support for his release.

It is unclear if Abdel Fattah will be able to travel to the UK to be with his son, though his sister said on his release that his release would "feel more real" when "his son arrives here from travelling".

The activist first rose to prominence during the 2011 uprising in Egypt that forced long-time President Hosni Mubarak to resign.

He has spent most of his time in prison since 2014, the year after Sisi led the military's overthrow of Egypt's first democratically elected president, Muslim Brotherhood leader Mohammed Morsi.

Sisi has overseen what human rights groups say is an unprecedented crackdown on dissent that has led to the detention of tens of thousands of people.

Although he acquired British citizenship in 2021, Egypt has never allowed him a consular visit by British diplomats.

In May, the UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention - a panel of independent human rights experts – found that Abdel Fattah had been arbitrarily arrested for exercising his right to freedom of expression, had not been given a fair trial and had remained in detention for his political opinions.

According to the panel, the Egyptian government said he had been afforded "all fair trial rights" and that his sentence would be completed in January 2027.
articles.reasoning: The article reports the release of a prominent political prisoner and pro-democracy activist after nearly six years in prison, highlighting a significant human rights development with broad societal impact. It focuses on a single, meaningful event with detailed context about the activist's imprisonment, family efforts, and international support, illustrating progress in human rights and freedom of expression.
articles.personality_title: British-Egyptian activist Alaa Abdel Fattah released after nearly six years in prison
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Alaa Abdel Fattah is a well-known British-Egyptian blogger and pro-democracy activist. He was arrested in Egypt in 2019 during a government crackdown on people who spoke out against the authorities. He was sentenced to five years in prison for sharing information about a prisoner who died under torture. His family and many international supporters campaigned for his release.

**What happened** – On Monday, Abdel Fattah was freed from Wadi al-Natrun prison after almost six years behind bars. His release came after Egyptian President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi pardoned him, following a request from the National Council for Human Rights. Video footage shows Abdel Fattah happily reuniting with his mother and sister at their home in Giza.

**Impact** – Abdel Fattah's release is important because he was one of Egypt’s most famous political prisoners. His family had called for his freedom, including his mother who went on a long hunger strike to demand his release. His case had attracted support from British politicians and human rights groups, highlighting concerns about freedom of expression and fair trials in Egypt.

**What’s next step** – It is not yet clear if Abdel Fattah will be able to travel to the UK to be with his son. His family hopes that his son will soon join him in Egypt. The release may also encourage more attention to the conditions of other political prisoners in Egypt and efforts to improve human rights there.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Alaa Abdel Fattah’s release after nearly six years in prison marks a key moment for human rights and political freedom in Egypt, following strong family and international support.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'activiste britannico-égyptien Alaa Abdel Fattah libéré après près de six ans de prison
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Alaa Abdel Fattah est un blogueur et militant pro-démocratie bien connu, de nationalité britannique et égyptienne. Il a été arrêté en Égypte en 2019 lors d'une répression contre ceux qui critiquaient le gouvernement. **Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, Abdel Fattah a été libéré de la prison de Wadi al-Natrun après presque six ans d’emprisonnement. Une vidéo montre Abdel Fattah heureux de retrouver sa mère et sa sœur chez eux au Caire.

**Impact** – La libération d’Abdel Fattah est importante car il était l’un des prisonniers politiques les plus connus d’Égypte. Sa famille avait appelé à sa libération, notamment sa mère qui avait entamé une longue grève de la faim pour demander sa sortie. Son cas avait reçu le soutien de politiciens britanniques et d’organisations de défense des droits humains, soulignant des préoccupations sur la liberté d’expression et l’équité des procès en Égypte.

Cette libération pourrait aussi attirer plus d’attention sur la situation d’autres prisonniers politiques en Égypte et sur les efforts pour améliorer les droits humains dans le pays.

**Une phrase à retenir** – La libération d’Alaa Abdel Fattah après presque six ans de prison marque un moment important pour les droits humains et la liberté politique en Égypte, grâce au soutien de sa famille et de la communauté internationale.
articles.personality_title_es: El activista británico-egipcio Alaa Abdel Fattah liberado tras casi seis años en prisión

Esta liberación también podría aumentar la atención sobre las condiciones de otros presos políticos en Egipto y los esfuerzos para mejorar los derechos humanos.

articles.title: New Industry Requirements Could Disrupt Abusive Armed Groups’ Trade in Gold
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              A gold miner carries a sack of rocks to a grinding mill at a mine in El Callao, Bolivar state, Venezuela, April 29, 2023.
                    © 2023 Matias Delacroix
          
    


  
Deep in the forest in Venezuela’s Bolivar state, residents live in fear of horrific violence at the hands of armed groups involved in the illicit gold trade. During a 2020 investigation, a 17-year-old boy told Human Rights Watch how he witnessed members of a Venezuelan armed group amputating both hands of a miner they accused of stealing gold. Summary executions and forced child labor by armed groups is still happening today.Much of the gold controlled by these groups is smuggled out of Venezuela and laundered in “transit countries” like Colombia, Guyana, and Brazil. With its origins now hidden or obscured, it is sold to companies in the United States, Canada, the EU, and elsewhere.A new requirement by the world’s leading gold refinery industry association, the London Bullion Market Association (LBMA), could help shed light on these illicit practices. According to the new rules, from 2026 onwards, refiners have to publicly disclose the identity of their suppliers from “red flag locations.” These are defined as regions where the gold “originates from or has been transported through a conflict-affected or high-risk area” characterized by armed conflict, political instability, repression, institutional weakness, or widespread human rights violations.This is good news. Opaque supply chains have benefited armed groups who profit from the gold trade in many parts of the world, including Venezuela, Sudan, and the Democratic Republic of Congo, to name just a few.Human Rights Watch has written to the LMBA calling on it to ensure that refiners apply the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s (OECD) definition of “red flag” locations properly, in line with OECD’s Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Supply Chains of Minerals from Conflict-Affected and High Risk Areas, and include countries where illicit gold is regularly transiting—such as Brazil and the UAE—in its the disclosures.Human Rights Watch has also called on the LBMA to require its refiners from 2027 to disclose the names and locations of all mines and all suppliers, not just those from “red flag locations.” Human rights violations can occur anywhere, and supply chain transparency can help identify abuses and abusers in global supply chains; an important step to ensuring respect for human rights.A more transparent gold trade is crucial to disrupting the financing and ending the abuses of armed groups in places like Venezuela. Public disclosures of refiners’ gold supply chains could help detect and diminish their illegal supply chains and curtail the horrific abuses that residents have been suffering for far too long.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image A gold miner carries a sack of rocks to a grinding mill at a mine in El Callao, Bolivar state, Venezuela, April 29, 2023. © 2023 Matias Delacroix

Deep in the forest in Venezuela’s Bolivar state, residents live in fear of horrific violence at the hands of armed groups involved in the illicit gold trade. During a 2020 investigation, a 17-year-old boy told Human Rights Watch how he witnessed members of a Venezuelan armed group amputating both hands of a miner they accused of stealing gold. Summary executions and forced child labor by armed groups is still happening today.

Much of the gold controlled by these groups is smuggled out of Venezuela and laundered in “transit countries” like Colombia, Guyana, and Brazil. With its origins now hidden or obscured, it is sold to companies in the United States, Canada, the EU, and elsewhere.

A new requirement by the world’s leading gold refinery industry association, the London Bullion Market Association (LBMA), could help shed light on these illicit practices. According to the new rules, from 2026 onwards, refiners have to publicly disclose the identity of their suppliers from “red flag locations.” These are defined as regions where the gold “originates from or has been transported through a conflict-affected or high-risk area” characterized by armed conflict, political instability, repression, institutional weakness, or widespread human rights violations.

This is good news. Opaque supply chains have benefited armed groups who profit from the gold trade in many parts of the world, including Venezuela, Sudan, and the Democratic Republic of Congo, to name just a few.

Human Rights Watch has written to the LMBA calling on it to ensure that refiners apply the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s (OECD) definition of “red flag” locations properly, in line with OECD’s Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Supply Chains of Minerals from Conflict-Affected and High Risk Areas, and include countries where illicit gold is regularly transiting—such as Brazil and the UAE—in its the disclosures.

Human Rights Watch has also called on the LBMA to require its refiners from 2027 to disclose the names and locations of all mines and all suppliers, not just those from “red flag locations.” Human rights violations can occur anywhere, and supply chain transparency can help identify abuses and abusers in global supply chains; an important step to ensuring respect for human rights.

A more transparent gold trade is crucial to disrupting the financing and ending the abuses of armed groups in places like Venezuela. Public disclosures of refiners’ gold supply chains could help detect and diminish their illegal supply chains and curtail the horrific abuses that residents have been suffering for far too long.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a new industry requirement by the London Bullion Market Association to increase transparency in gold supply chains originating from conflict-affected areas, which is expected to disrupt financing of abusive armed groups and reduce human rights violations. This policy change has broad significance for global human rights and supply chain ethics, with detailed context on the problem and the proposed solution.
articles.personality_title: New gold rules aim to stop armed groups from profiting in Venezuela
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Venezuela’s Bolivar state, armed groups control much of the gold trade through violence and illegal means. They use fear, forced child labor, and brutal punishments to keep control. The gold is smuggled through nearby countries like Colombia, Guyana, and Brazil, then sold in places like the US, Canada, and Europe, hiding its troubled origins.

**What happened** – The London Bullion Market Association (LBMA), which represents the world’s top gold refineries, announced new rules starting in 2026. These rules require refiners to publicly name their suppliers if the gold comes from or passes through conflict or high-risk areas, called “red flag locations.” This aims to make the gold supply chain more open and traceable.

**Impact** – This change is important because it challenges the secret trade that funds armed groups known for violence and human rights abuses. By making suppliers known, it becomes harder for illegal gold to enter the market unnoticed. Groups in Venezuela and other countries will find it more difficult to profit from gold mined under dangerous and unfair conditions.

**What’s next step** – Human Rights Watch is urging the LBMA to apply strict standards for identifying risky areas and to expand transparency by 2027 to include all mines and suppliers, not just those in “red flag” zones. This broader openness could help spot abuses everywhere and encourage companies to act responsibly.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New rules requiring gold refiners to reveal suppliers from conflict zones aim to cut off funding for armed groups and reduce violence linked to illegal gold mining.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouvelles règles sur l’or pour freiner les groupes armés au Venezuela
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Dans l’État de Bolívar au Venezuela, des groupes armés contrôlent le commerce de l’or par la violence et des pratiques illégales. Ils utilisent la peur, le travail forcé des enfants et des punitions brutales pour garder le contrôle. L’or est ensuite passé en contrebande par des pays voisins comme la Colombie, le Guyana et le Brésil, puis vendu aux États-Unis, au Canada et en Europe, cachant ainsi son origine problématique.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La London Bullion Market Association (LBMA), qui représente les principales raffineries d’or mondiales, a annoncé de nouvelles règles à partir de 2026. Ces règles obligent les raffineurs à divulguer publiquement l’identité de leurs fournisseurs si l’or provient ou transite par des zones de conflit ou à risque, appelées « lieux à drapeau rouge ». L’objectif est de rendre la chaîne d’approvisionnement de l’or plus transparente et traçable.

**Impact** – Ce changement est important car il met au défi le commerce secret qui finance des groupes armés connus pour leurs violences et violations des droits humains. En rendant les fournisseurs connus, il devient plus difficile pour l’or illégal d’entrer sur le marché sans être détecté. Les groupes au Venezuela et ailleurs auront plus de mal à tirer profit de l’or extrait dans des conditions dangereuses et injustes.

**Prochaine étape** – Human Rights Watch encourage la LBMA à appliquer des normes strictes pour identifier les zones à risque et à étendre la transparence dès 2027 à toutes les mines et fournisseurs, pas seulement ceux des zones « à drapeau rouge ». Cette ouverture plus large pourrait aider à détecter les abus partout et encourager les entreprises à agir de manière responsable.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouvelles règles obligeant les raffineurs d’or à révéler les fournisseurs des zones de conflit visent à couper le financement des groupes armés et à réduire la violence liée à l’exploitation illégale de l’or.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas reglas sobre el oro buscan frenar a grupos armados en Venezuela
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En el estado Bolívar de Venezuela, grupos armados controlan gran parte del comercio ilegal de oro mediante violencia y prácticas ilegales. Usan el miedo, trabajo infantil forzado y castigos brutales para mantener el control. El oro se contrabandea por países vecinos como Colombia, Guyana y Brasil, y luego se vende en EE. UU., Canadá y Europa, ocultando su origen problemático.

**Qué pasó** – La London Bullion Market Association (LBMA), que representa a las principales refinerías de oro del mundo, anunció nuevas reglas que entrarán en vigor en 2026. Estas reglas exigen que los refinadores revelen públicamente a sus proveedores si el oro proviene o pasa por zonas de conflicto o de alto riesgo, llamadas “ubicaciones con bandera roja”. Esto busca hacer la cadena de suministro más transparente y rastreable.

**Impacto** – Este cambio es importante porque dificulta el comercio secreto que financia a grupos armados conocidos por violencia y violaciones de derechos humanos. Al hacer públicos los proveedores, será más difícil que el oro ilegal ingrese al mercado sin ser detectado. Los grupos en Venezuela y otros países tendrán menos posibilidades de beneficiarse del oro extraído en condiciones peligrosas e injustas.

**Próximo paso** – Human Rights Watch pide a la LBMA que aplique estrictamente los estándares para identificar zonas riesgosas y que, a partir de 2027, amplíe la transparencia para incluir todas las minas y proveedores, no solo los de zonas “con bandera roja”. Esta mayor apertura podría ayudar a detectar abusos en todas partes y motivar a las empresas a actuar responsablemente.

**Resumen en una frase** – Nuevas reglas que exigen a los refinadores de oro revelar proveedores de zonas de conflicto buscan cortar el financiamiento a grupos armados y reducir la violencia ligada a la minería ilegal.

articles.title: High-level week opens with celebration of women’s empowerment
articles.summary: Only the fifth woman to preside over the UN General Assembly in its 80-year history has praised the courage of those “who fought for every phrase, every word in the Beijing Declaration,” marking the 30th Anniversary of the pivotal international conference on women’s empowerment.
articles.content:
During the landmark 1995 event in the Chinese capital, countries came together and adopted the Beijing Declaration – a blueprint document for advancing women’s rights (read our explainer, here).

At the high-level celebratory event on Monday, countries, civil society organizations, and representatives from academia and the private sector discussed how to accelerate its implementation.

“For so many of us here in this room, we hold positions that when we ourselves were young, seemed unattainable, but are now almost normal for the next generation,” said Annalena Baerbock, referring to the notion that “women’s rights are human rights,” – the rallying cry from First Lady Hillary Clinton 30 years ago in Beijing.

Soundcloud

Most ambitious commitment

UN Secretary General António Guterres described the declaration as “the most ambitious global political commitment on women’s rights ever achieved,” adding that it has helped advance legal protection, political participation and education for women worldwide.

Executive Director of gender-equality agency UN Women Sima Bahous remarked that girls are far more likely to finish school today, than at any other time in history.

The number of women in parliament has almost doubled and nearly 100 discriminatory laws have been reversed around the world in the past five years alone.

“Every step forward proved the same truth: gender equality works,” Ms. Bahous said. “But progress has not been fast enough.”

Soundcloud

‘No more promises’

A new report from UN Women released earlier this month found that none of the gender equality Sustainable Development Goals are on track. Furthermore, 676 million women and girls now live under the shadow of deadly conflict – the highest recorded since the 1990s.

Cecilia Suárez, UN Global Advocate for the UN Spotlight Initiative, a groundbreaking programme designed to end violence against women and girls, said it had shown “it is possible to make positive and concrete results in this fight.”

“What is required is leadership from those who have gathered here. Leadership that fosters reforms,” she added.

Speaking about the many women around the world who continue to experience injustice, human rights activist and Yazidi survivor of ISIL terrorist sex traffickers, Nadia Murad, called on the international community to fund women’s organisations on the frontlines, guarantee women’s participation in peace and security, and hold perpetrators accountable.

“The next generation of women and girls deserve to inherit no more promises but the reality of justice, equality and dignity,” said Ms. Murad.

Check out a recording below of Celia Suárez at the UNGA80 SDG Media Zone on Monday, talking about the Spotlight Initiative and her role as Global Advocate since 2020.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the 30th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration, a landmark global commitment to women's rights, and celebrates measurable progress in gender equality such as increased education and political participation for women worldwide. It also discusses ongoing challenges and the need for leadership and funding to accelerate change, focusing on a significant human rights issue with broad societal impact.
articles.personality_title: UN marks 30 years since Beijing Declaration with focus on women's progress and challenges
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 1995, countries around the world came together in Beijing to adopt the Beijing Declaration, a plan to improve women's rights everywhere. This year marks the 30th anniversary of this important event.

**What happened** – On Monday, a high-level event at the United Nations brought together leaders, organizations, and experts to celebrate progress made since the declaration and discuss how to speed up change. Annalena Baerbock, the fifth woman to lead the UN General Assembly, spoke about how women's rights have become more accepted, and UN leaders shared facts about improvements in education and politics for women.

**Impact** – The declaration has led to more girls finishing school and more women joining parliaments worldwide. Nearly 100 unfair laws against women have been removed in the last five years. Despite this, progress is slow, and many women still face violence and injustice, especially in conflict zones. The event highlighted that real leadership and support are needed to turn promises into real change.

**What's next step** – Leaders and advocates called for more funding for women's groups and for women to be included in peace and security decisions. They also stressed the importance of holding those who harm women responsible. The goal is to ensure the next generation experiences equality and justice, not just promises.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Thirty years after the Beijing Declaration, the world has made important strides for women's rights but must now act faster and stronger to achieve real equality and safety for all women.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'ONU célèbre les 30 ans de la Déclaration de Beijing en soulignant les progrès et défis pour les femmes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 1995, des pays du monde entier se sont réunis à Beijing pour adopter la Déclaration de Beijing, un plan pour améliorer les droits des femmes partout. Cette année marque le 30e anniversaire de cet événement important.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Lundi, un événement de haut niveau aux Nations Unies a réuni des dirigeants, des organisations et des experts pour célébrer les progrès réalisés depuis la déclaration et discuter de la façon d'accélérer le changement. Annalena Baerbock, la cinquième femme à présider l'Assemblée générale de l'ONU, a parlé de la reconnaissance croissante des droits des femmes, et les dirigeants de l'ONU ont partagé des faits sur l'amélioration de l'éducation et de la participation politique des femmes.

**Impact** – La déclaration a permis à plus de filles de terminer leurs études et à plus de femmes de rejoindre les parlements dans le monde. Près de 100 lois discriminatoires contre les femmes ont été supprimées ces cinq dernières années. Malgré cela, les progrès restent lents et de nombreuses femmes subissent encore violence et injustice, surtout en zones de conflit. L'événement a souligné que le vrai leadership et le soutien sont nécessaires pour transformer les promesses en changements concrets.

**Prochaine étape** – Les dirigeants et défenseurs ont demandé plus de financements pour les groupes de femmes et la participation des femmes aux décisions de paix et de sécurité. Ils ont aussi insisté sur la nécessité de punir ceux qui violent les droits des femmes. L'objectif est que la prochaine génération vive dans l'égalité et la justice, pas seulement avec des promesses.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Trente ans après la Déclaration de Beijing, le monde a fait des progrès importants pour les droits des femmes, mais doit maintenant agir plus vite et plus fort pour garantir l'égalité et la sécurité pour toutes.
articles.personality_title_es: La ONU celebra 30 años de la Declaración de Beijing destacando avances y desafíos para las mujeres
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 1995, países de todo el mundo se reunieron en Beijing para adoptar la Declaración de Beijing, un plan para mejorar los derechos de las mujeres en todas partes. Este año se cumple el 30º aniversario de este evento importante.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, un evento de alto nivel en las Naciones Unidas reunió a líderes, organizaciones y expertos para celebrar los avances desde la declaración y discutir cómo acelerar el cambio. Annalena Baerbock, la quinta mujer en presidir la Asamblea General de la ONU, habló sobre cómo los derechos de las mujeres son ahora más reconocidos, y líderes de la ONU compartieron datos sobre mejoras en la educación y participación política de las mujeres.

**Impacto** – La declaración ha permitido que más niñas terminen la escuela y que más mujeres entren en parlamentos en todo el mundo. Casi 100 leyes discriminatorias contra mujeres han sido eliminadas en los últimos cinco años. A pesar de esto, el progreso es lento y muchas mujeres aún enfrentan violencia e injusticia, especialmente en zonas de conflicto. El evento destacó que se necesita un liderazgo real y apoyo para convertir las promesas en cambios reales.

**Próximo paso** – Líderes y defensores pidieron más fondos para grupos de mujeres y que las mujeres participen en decisiones de paz y seguridad. También enfatizaron la importancia de responsabilizar a quienes dañan a las mujeres. El objetivo es que la próxima generación viva con igualdad y justicia, no solo con promesas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Treinta años después de la Declaración de Beijing, el mundo ha logrado avances importantes en los derechos de las mujeres, pero ahora debe actuar más rápido y con más fuerza para lograr igualdad y seguridad para todas.

articles.title: EU is working on credit for Ukraine from Russian assets
articles.summary: According to the EU Commission's proposals, money for Ukraine can also come from frozen Russian assets.
articles.content:
According to the EU Commission’s proposals, money for Ukraine can also come from frozen Russian assets.

Copenhagen (dpa) – According to the European Commission, EU countries are open to a loan for Ukraine from the custody of frozen Russian assets. “The member states see this as a possible way forward,” said EU Economic Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis after a meeting with the finance ministers of the member states. Overall, there is a willingness for constructive cooperation.

Work is now continuing on the exact design, Dombrovskis said. Time is pressing: Ukraine needs the financing starting in 2026.

Russian state assets frozen in the EU

Due to the war of aggression against Ukraine, around 200 billion euros of the Russian central bank have been frozen in the EU, according to Commission information. The interest income is already being used to finance weapons and ammunition for Ukraine. Now the EU Commission wants to go further.

The EU Commission is currently working on the design of a new loan for Ukraine, which is to be financed by Russian state assets set in the EU. The rough idea is to make freed Russian assets available to Ukraine as a loan. The EU countries are to guarantee this loan.

Expropriation not planned

This means that the assets themselves remain untouched. Proposals to use the money directly through an expropriation decision are highly controversial. Among others, the German government is skeptical of the idea. There are concerns that other countries might also withdraw their state funds invested in Europe.

How large the loan should be still needs to be determined, said EU Economic Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis. However, it is already clear that Ukraine should only have to repay the loan once Russia finances reparations in the country. The former EU member Great Britain is planning a similar mechanism. (September 20)
articles.reasoning: The EU's proposal to provide Ukraine with a loan financed by frozen Russian assets represents a significant and constructive financial support measure amid the ongoing conflict. This initiative has broad implications for supporting Ukraine's sovereignty and recovery, with a clear plan and timeline, and involves cooperation among multiple countries. It addresses a major humanitarian and geopolitical issue with tangible benefits for a nation affected by war.
articles.personality_title: EU plans loan for Ukraine using frozen Russian assets
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) has frozen about 200 billion euros of Russian state money in response to Russia’s war against Ukraine. So far, the EU has used the interest from this money to help pay for weapons for Ukraine.

**What happened** – The EU Commission proposed a new idea: to offer Ukraine a loan using these frozen Russian funds. EU countries agree this could work, but the money itself won’t be taken away permanently. Instead, the loan would be guaranteed by EU countries and Ukraine would repay it only after Russia pays reparations.

**Impact** – This plan is important because it provides Ukraine with financial support starting in 2026 without permanently taking Russian assets. It shows cooperation among EU countries and offers Ukraine a way to fund its recovery while keeping legal and diplomatic concerns in mind.

**What's next step** – EU officials will now work on the details of the loan, including how much money will be lent and the exact rules. Other countries like the UK are thinking about similar ideas to support Ukraine.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is creating a loan for Ukraine backed by frozen Russian assets, offering financial help while respecting legal limits and international cooperation.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE prépare un prêt pour l’Ukraine avec les avoirs russes gelés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) a gelé environ 200 milliards d’euros d’avoirs russes en réponse à la guerre de la Russie contre l’Ukraine. Jusqu’à présent, l’UE utilise les intérêts de cet argent pour financer des armes pour l’Ukraine.

Les pays de l’UE sont d’accord pour que cela fonctionne, mais l’argent ne sera pas pris définitivement. Le prêt serait garanti par les pays de l’UE et l’Ukraine le remboursera seulement après que la Russie paiera des réparations.

Il montre la coopération entre les pays de l’UE et donne à l’Ukraine un moyen de financer sa reconstruction tout en respectant les règles légales et diplomatiques.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’UE prépare un prêt pour l’Ukraine garanti par des avoirs russes gelés, apportant une aide financière tout en respectant les limites légales et la coopération internationale.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE plane un préstamo para Ucrania con activos rusos congelados
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) ha congelado alrededor de 200 mil millones de euros de dinero estatal ruso debido a la guerra de Rusia contra Ucrania. Hasta ahora, la UE ha usado los intereses de este dinero para financiar armas para Ucrania.

**Qué pasó** – La Comisión Europea propuso una nueva idea: ofrecer a Ucrania un préstamo usando estos fondos rusos congelados. Los países de la UE están de acuerdo en que esto podría funcionar, pero el dinero no se tomará de forma permanente. En cambio, el préstamo sería garantizado por los países de la UE y Ucrania lo pagará solo después de que Rusia pague reparaciones.

**Impacto** – Este plan es importante porque da apoyo financiero a Ucrania a partir de 2026 sin quedarse con los activos rusos para siempre. Muestra cooperación entre los países de la UE y ofrece a Ucrania una forma de financiar su recuperación respetando las leyes y la diplomacia.

**Próximo paso** – Los funcionarios de la UE ahora trabajarán en los detalles del préstamo, como cuánto dinero se prestará y las reglas exactas. Otros países como el Reino Unido están pensando en ideas similares para apoyar a Ucrania.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La UE está creando un préstamo para Ucrania respaldado por activos rusos congelados, ofreciendo ayuda financiera mientras respeta los límites legales y la cooperación internacional.
